awd_titl_txt: Design Guidelines for High Strength Multicomponent Alloys
awd_abstract_narration:
A new class of alloys called  "High Entropy Alloys" is emerging as candidate materials for high strength applications. These alloys have very complex chemistries and are composed of a large number of elements. The processes by which they deform are also complex. This award supports research to understand deformation and fracture behavior of these alloys.  The researchers seek to understand how the complex composition of these materials can be used to advantage the search of high strength and ductile alloys. By varying different compositional and processing parameters, it is expected that useful criteria may be found to optimize the combination of strength and ductility. The research will be incorporated in curriculum development for the education of future generations of researchers that are trained to use these computational tools in combination with experiments. The project contributes to the education of high school and undergraduate students through web educational modules used in undergraduate and graduate courses, summer camps, and internships. These instructional materials are geared particularly for female students to encourage their participation in this field.  

This research effort is based on the hypothesis that by varying atomic interaction parameters, useful criteria can be found to optimize the combination of strength and ductility. Because of limitations in the number of atoms that can be studied using first principle calculations, the researchers will utilize simple model interaction potentials for various degrees of variation in atomic sizes, cohesive energies, and chemical interaction.  They will obtain trends in strength and fracture toughness as a function of these varying degrees of complexity.  These trends will be compared with available experimental studies of the mechanical behavior of various high entropy alloys that indicate increased ductility while maintaining high strength.  The methodology developed here for model interactions provides a basis for future computational modeling.  Most importantly, the insight provided by this work enable more efficient design of single-phase high entropy alloys for a variety of applications.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

por.por_cntn:
For all the work under this project, a clear focus was on understanding the role of compositional fluctuations in these novel complex materials. This was achieved by comparing results with those obtained using an aveage atom potential, which the same overall properties but no compositional fluctuations.  this technique can provide insight not available through experiments alone. 

            Some of the significant results obtained are::

1. Compositional fluctuations in HEA complex materials result in more difficult dislocation glide and therefore more difficult deformation.  This contributes to additional strength. 

2. The  initial defromation in HEA nanowires  can occur at  a lower applied stress because of the compositional fluctuations. This effect can contribute to additional ductility. 

3. Compositional fluctuations in these materials do not always result in slower, or "sluggish" diffusion behavior. 

4. Simple empirical interatomic potentials can be used in understanding general trends , as those mentioned above. The potetials developed in this work are available for the gneral use of the computtional materials community. 


This project contributed to the general understanding of the role of compositional fluctuations in the mechanical and diffusion response of these materials. The trends observed can explain the fact that in these alloys one can obtain improved combinations of strength and ductility. 

 


Last Modified: 02/23/2023
Modified by: Diana Farkas

This was achieved by comparing results with those obtained using an aveage atom potential, which the same overall properties but no compositional fluctuations.  this technique can provide insight not available through experiments alone. 

            Some of the significant results obtained are::


1. Compositional fluctuations in HEA complex materials result in more difficult dislocation glide and therefore more difficult deformation.  This contributes to additional strength. 

2. The  initial defromation in HEA nanowires  can occur at  a lower applied stress because of the compositional fluctuations. This effect can contribute to additional ductility. 

3. Compositional fluctuations in these materials do not always result in slower, or "sluggish" diffusion behavior. 

4. Simple empirical interatomic potentials can be used in understanding general trends , as those mentioned above. The potetials developed in this work are available for the gneral use of the computtional materials community.
